Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned about the history of chemical weapons, submarines, air raids, mines, nuclear weapons, and biological weapons. This course identified many themes in regards to arms control and examined the philosophy and ideology driving weapons sanctions.
This Course was great in teaching primary source analysis, especially of treaties, agreements, legislation, and public opinion.
I learned a lot about the history of US Arms control, a topic I previously knew nothing about. I also feel as though I developed my research skills and my comfort in a seminar setting.
During the course of the semester, I vastly improved my document analysis skills via the weekly document analysis presentations and the research paper project.

This was a very well organized seminar and a great introduction to the methodology of a historian. In addition to learning about arms control, we gained experience in sources analysis and essay structure.
It felt a little repetitive at times regarding the subject material

The strengths are the accessibility of the professor and the interesting content. I feel like a weakness was the lack of discussion in seminar, the classes usually turned into a fairly straightforward analysis of the facts in the readings as opposed to meaningful debates or conversations between students.
Incredible class with incredible professor. John Maurer is an excellent discussion leader.

I believe that the strengths of the course are the instructor, Professor Maurer, as he is extremely engaging and really wants to help all of the students improve their ability to read and analyze historical documents.
I would recommend this course to any student interested in arms control or who wants to be in a seminar that develops good practices for becoming a historian.
Excellent course. Interesting material, great instructor, not too heavy of a workload
Yes, especially if you're interested in a history seminar but don't know where to start!

This was a very solid and well-taught class with a professor who is very excited about the material. I wish more discussions could have been had that extended beyond the details of the reading but great class
Yes, learned a lot about an area I didnt know much about. Great professor who is very knowledgeable about the course.

Class is focused on writing skills and the professor does an amazing job of preparing history students to collect, analyze, and write about primary sources. Great course to take if you want writing practice for the senior thesis

Yes, I would recommend this course to any student interested in 20th-century international affairs or military history. The readings and discussions are phenomenal, and I think any Yale student would gain a lot from the course.
